docs.snippet: SUMMER entertaining demands ease and quantity. Weekend guests multiply and a crowd is best served with dishes that can be prepared in advance and be presented buffet style.     If the ingredients are readily available and do not make serious inroa...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant column offers easy summer chicken and salad recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SUMMER entertaining demands ease and quantity. Weekend guests multiply and a crowd is best served with dishes that can be prepared in advance and be presented buffet style. If the ingredients are readily available and do not make serious inroads on the budget, so much the better. A platter of baked chicken, a bowl of coleslaw and a white bean salad make up just such a menu. Some cheeses, salami, olives and bread with drinks, and icy wedges of watermelon for dessert with cookies or brownies are simple additions to round out the party.

headline.main: Summer Entertaining for a Crowd That's Easy and Sumptuous

docs.snippet: WHAT could be more sublime than potatoes, garlic and cream? The alchemy of the combination, gratin dauphinois, has all the understated extravagance of a $100,000 strand of South Seas pearls.    Some recipes for gratin dauphinois include cheese, li...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant article on preparing potatoes gratin; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT could be more sublime than potatoes, garlic and cream? The alchemy of the combination, gratin dauphinois, has all the understated extravagance of a $100,000 strand of South Seas pearls. Some recipes for gratin dauphinois include cheese, like Gruyere, either grated on top or layered with the potatoes. Others insist on a dusting of bread crumbs. There is nothing wrong with these embellishments. It is just that the dish is so sumptuous without them, why bother?

headline.main: Potatoes Made Sumptuous With Garlic and Cream

docs.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS DAY weekend is an appropriate time to celebrate the culinary legacy of the Western Hemisphere. Who does not know that tomatoes, potatoes, corn, beans, squashes and peppers are New World crops unknown in Europe before 1492?

headline.main: Dishes That Celebrate the Bounty of the New World

docs.snippet: Let us praise the ruby-red beet. its versatility and sweet sturdiness are to be admired and extolled. And yet the beet remains the problem child of the root-vegetable world. Throughout history, talented chefs have sought to boost it up the social ...
docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill's column on cooking with ruby-red beets; dishes of chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten discussed; recipes; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Let us praise the ruby-red beet. its versatility and sweet sturdiness are to be admired and extolled. And yet the beet remains the problem child of the root-vegetable world. Throughout history, talented chefs have sought to boost it up the social scale. Usually to no avail. No, the beet seems destined to be humble, always linked to borscht and one-pot dishes born of adversity. While foods of equally low pedigree have somehow managed to overcome their origins and become the affectations of the privileged, the beet remains suspect. At least so far.

docs.snippet: Moving around the kitchen at the center of his home in Palo Alto, Calif., Harold McGee is part poet, part mad scientist, part dad who cooks. His primary goal this afternoon is to make dinner for his wife, Sharon Long, a chemistry professor at Stan...
docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill column on the cooking of Harold McGee, author of On Food and Cooking, a book on biochemistry of food; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Moving around the kitchen at the center of his home in Palo Alto, Calif., Harold McGee is part poet, part mad scientist, part dad who cooks. His primary goal this afternoon is to make dinner for his wife, Sharon Long, a chemistry professor at Stanford, and his kids, John, 11, and Florence, 9. But first, he insists I try some of his collard green ''leather,'' which has more calcium per spoonful, he exclaims, than a glass of milk. But that's nothing compared with the excitement he feels about the milk, cream, custard and ice cream he can now derive from hazelnuts.

docs.snippet: WHAT is more suggestive of spring than baby vegetables? Bunches of tiny carrots, downy pods of fava beans, miniature artichokes, thin-skinned potatoes no bigger than golf balls and skinny asparagus and French haricots verts can inspire soups, sala...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant article on cooking baby vegetables; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT is more suggestive of spring than baby vegetables? Bunches of tiny carrots, downy pods of fava beans, miniature artichokes, thin-skinned potatoes no bigger than golf balls and skinny asparagus and French haricots verts can inspire soups, salads and even a rich but light main-dish ragout.

headline.main: Medley of Baby Vegetables, Light but Rich

docs.snippet: Second only to the question of which came first, the chicken or the egg, is that other confounding enigma: Which is more useful, the white or the yolk?    The yolk, of course, can inspire poetry, in the kitchen and on the page. It has a rich, sati...
docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill Food column on whipping egg whites; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Second only to the question of which came first, the chicken or the egg, is that other confounding enigma: Which is more useful, the white or the yolk? The yolk, of course, can inspire poetry, in the kitchen and on the page. It has a rich, satiny character. And when we think of it at all, we think of it as a smooth, full life. The white, on the other hand, is a liquid that exists in sublimation to its mate. Taken together, yolk and white are a perfect, self-contained world. Taken separately, they are an elliptical yin and yang.

docs.snippet: WEIGHING THE MERITS OF THE KNOWN against a leap into the unfamiliar is a dance between the mundane and the risky. Meatloaf, for instance, is safe; curried meatloaf, on the other hand, requires courage. The more familiar a dish, the more freighted ...
docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill column gives several meatloaf recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WEIGHING THE MERITS OF THE KNOWN against a leap into the unfamiliar is a dance between the mundane and the risky. Meatloaf, for instance, is safe; curried meatloaf, on the other hand, requires courage. The more familiar a dish, the more freighted the improvisation. And yet the urge to improvise seems to increase in direct proportion to the risks that attend it. Reinvention is as fundamental to the American kitchen as it is to the nation's psyche. Where else, after all, can you achieve perfect pitch? Where but the kitchen can you address an era's unspoken desires by merely amending its meat and potatoes? In America, where our pantry and our precepts are global, we have the possibility of creating in one glorious dish the world as we wish it to be.

docs.snippet: Glitz and glitter, caviar and champagne are to New Year's Eve what coals are to New Castle. If, by the final day of December, your taste for traditional holiday indulgences has not been satisfied, chances are it never will. Such is the fate of any...
docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill column gives hors d'oeuvres recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Glitz and glitter, caviar and champagne are to New Year's Eve what coals are to New Castle. If, by the final day of December, your taste for traditional holiday indulgences has not been satisfied, chances are it never will. Such is the fate of any luxury that becomes routine. Generally, what you need is an antidote. A tonic to revive a spirit dulled by too much of a good thing. In these situations, the appetite turns to dishes that require some puttering and simmering. All the better if such food delivers some folk wisdom as well.

docs.snippet: BEETS, with their deep red color and earthy flavor, are among my favorite fall vegetables. They make wonderful warm salads paired with peppery vegetables like watercress or endive, and they can be flavored with herbs, orange sections, toasted waln...
docs.abstract: Moria Hodgson column on cooking beets; recipes (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: BEETS, with their deep red color and earthy flavor, are among my favorite fall vegetables. They make wonderful warm salads paired with peppery vegetables like watercress or endive, and they can be flavored with herbs, orange sections, toasted walnuts, sesame seeds or pecans. The greens are delicious, too, cooked and tossed in a vinaigrette dressing. Both beets and their greens are good served as part of an antipasto with prosciutto, bresaola, smoked fish or a coarse country pate.

headline.main: Warm Up Salads With Cooked Beets
